Posts.Content: Jan 26, 2009 08:58AM PSK07 wrote: Your insurance should have an appeal process.  Talk to the radiologist and they should resubmit the billing according to that process.  Insurance companies often reject these tests hoping that you won't call their bluff and appeal.  It would be better if they'd do that before you have the test... Good luck.
Posts.Title: Insurance company will not cover my MRI blas dlb823

Posts.Content: Jan 29, 2009 03:49PM PSK07 wrote: While calling attention to this in Washington may be a good idea, I urge anyone who has unresolved issues with their insurance company to consider contacting their State Insurance Commissioner.  Most insurance policy coverage requirements are set at the state, not national, level. If you are covered by an employer, and that employer is self-insured, it becomes more difficult, but not impossible to get things turned around. In Washington State we have a very consumer-oriented insurance commission. We have also pioneered requiring some medical treatments be provided by insurors offering group coverage in the state.  Things such as mental health parity, alternative/complementary medicine, etc. In many cases, if it looks like they company will continue to deny, deny, deny, one letter to the Ins Commissioner and cc'd to the insurance company (or vice versa) will do the trick.  My mother initially had her treatment for BC denied because the insurance co. decided it was a pre-existing condition (she changed companies about 3 months prior to her dx). It took her surgeon, PCP, and onc, along with a well-timed letter to the State to get the decision turned around.
Posts.Title: Insurance company will not cover my MRI blas dlb823

Posts.Content: Apr 19, 2008 09:03PM PSK07 wrote: ftreloar, with pure DCIS, Her2 status is irrelevent and doesn't mean more or less aggressive. It means nothing. That said, I honestly don't know the impact with a micro invasion. Those few cells, though, move you up from Stage 0 to Stage 1. From what women here have said, micromets with DCIS usually don't mean chemo.  The ER/PR - does mean that you can't use a hormonals like Tamoxifen, so making sure you get the right and best treatment is the most important thing. Odds are they will do a sentinal node biopsy along with your lumpectomy which will check for anything further.  With grade 3 DCIS, the rads are imperative, especially with ER-/PR- status. If you go down the page of topics a bit, there is a discussion on DCIS and one of the regular posters, Beesie, did have a micro invasion with her DCIS and has lots of info and research which might help resolve some of the confusion. Take care..best to you.

From his office staff to the nurses in the hospital to an ultrasound tech I saw last month, I heard nothing but praise for him, his skill and his ability to connect with his patients. He does all kinds of surgeries, including plenty on breasts, and I was more than thrilled with how things turned out. Good rep, in practice for years, no complaints on the State web site - should be fine. I hope the doctor is a good fit for you.

Posts.Content: Oct 22, 2008 10:58AM PSK07 wrote: Talika, the surgeon shouldn't mind. I was referred to an Onc that was not a good fit. She said to get into an Oncologist and talk risk.  Of course, I was almost immediately thereafter dx with LCIS (and probably ALH), so seeing someone was no longer a choice. Anyway, I found one by asking the Radiologist when she called with the latest Dx. She recommended someone at another hospital. As it happens, the onc went out on 6 weeks medical, so I ended up with someone else in that office. Wonderful. She deals only with breast cancer, and one of her particular specialties is risk.  After my surgery we'll meet again and discuss Tamoxifen and whatever else I have to do to keep the bad cells at bay. Good luck to you. Long story short, get in to see an oncologist who will talk risk factors and what you can do.

Posts.Content: Mar 17, 2008 06:44PM PSK07 wrote: I had an MRI post biopsy, pre-surgery. It did pick up something, so it was followed-up with an ultrasound and then an ultrasound-guided biopsy. It turned out to be b9. One way to reduce false-positives is to have the MRI around 7-10 days after the start of your period.  One day they'll figure out how to eliminate the false positives, but til then I'm just happy they have another way to check out younger, denser breasts. My surgeon recommended that my sisters have MRIs and also recommends that I have mammos alternating with MRIs every 6 months for the next three years.

Posts.Content: Nov 9, 2008 09:29PM PSK07 wrote: Hi, Lucy Welcome.  As you've found out Breast Cancer and its precursors can be mighty confusing. ALH is certainly in a gray area.  ALH is typically an incidental finding, that is it is diagnosed because they do a biopsy for something else.  So, in your case, they did the biopsy and whatever they were looking at was benign, but in the tissue they found the ALH. Since it doesn't present as a lump or lesion, it's just there in the lobules, they don't do other surgery.  ALH is defined as an overactive growth of cells in the milk glands. In the results of one study shown here at bc.org, looking at certain non-cancerous lumps they found the following: http://community.breastcancer.org/forum/83/topic/724179 The researchers then looked for any relationships between the different breast cancer risk factors. They found that for women diagnosed with atypical hyperplasia, the age at diagnosis made a difference. When compared to the average woman in the SEER registry: Women younger than 45 with atypical hyperplasia were seven times more likely to develop breast cancer. Women between 45 and 55 with atypical hyperplasia were five times more likely to develop breast cancer. Women older than 55 with atypical hyperplasia were three times more likely to develop breast cancer. It's important to note that, for women with non-proliferative breast lumps who had a weak or no family history of breast cancer, there was NO increase in the risk of breast cancer. I read this a couple of weeks ago, right after I had surgery to remove some LCIS that was in a nodule - in the pathology for that nodule, they found ALH in a number of the tissue slices. Scary stuff.  But, the good news is not cancerous.  I'll have lots of monitoring until I go through menopause and my breasts aren't dense.  As my surgeon said, though, he cuts, oncologists treat. I met with an oncologist prior to surgery and am meeting with her again this week to go over the results and discuss risk & most likely get a prescription for Tamoxifen. The onc I was referred to treats only breast cancer & has a particular interest in risk factors and genetics. She seems a good fit. (One I saw last year after my DCIS dx wasn't.) After you see an oncologist you should have a better understanding of your risk factors and get some guidance on the treatment options and monitoring that are right for you. Good luck and take care. Oh - look at the LCIS discussion a bit down the board. WHile you don't have LCIS, there are a number of women who have both & will have some insight.
Posts.Title: ALH Diagnosis and thinking about a Second Opinion lucy3 EleanorJ

Posts.Content: Nov 10, 2008 07:23AM PSK07 wrote: Lucy - you should be able to get a referral to an oncologist from your surgeon or PCP.  I asked "my" radiologist (she's done 4 biopsies on me now) if she knew of someone. Since I wasn't thrilled with who I was referred to last year, and while the others in that office are good, I wanted to see a woman.  She told me of one at another hospital & I was able to set up an appointment on my own. Seeing an oncologist, even without having a cancer dx, is important because your risk of developing invasive BC is higher.  The onc will be able to talk to your risk factors, family history, current diagnosis, and recommend a treatment/preventative course of action.  S/he may end up sending you back to your PCP for prescriptions/mammo/MRI scheduling, but it is good to at least talk to an expert. I was 47 when I received this diagnosis. My current recs are: Alternate mammograms and MRIs every 6 months, clinical breast exams, and tamoxifen for 5 years.
Posts.Title: ALH Diagnosis and thinking about a Second Opinion lucy3 EleanorJ

Posts.Content: Apr 30, 2008 11:52PM PSK07 wrote: Aloe Vera gel - pure. Morning, noon (I had rads at 4pm), after rads, bed time. Aquaphor lotion - nights (wear old tees or camis cause it goops everything up)  Lie around the house topless. Someone could make a million devising a boob sling to gently hold the boob up so air gets to the icky skin. Domeboro solution - can buy at RiteAid, but isn't cheap. Use one packet in 1 cup of water, soak a washcloth in it and lay the cloth on your breast. (Rad nurse gave me what I needed.) Gel pads - there are different ones. Again, rad nurse provided them to me. One weekend I got desperate and used something called BurnGel that has lidocaine in it to soothe the pain. What I found was if I asked the nurses, they gave me things. Even better was when the techs noticed the skin situation & they went and got the nurse.  Given how much we pay for the rads, they should give us all the SE treatments we need! good luck and good healing.

Posts.Content: Jan 19, 2008 06:40PM PSK07 wrote: Karen - my surgeon and radiation oncologists were very much against mammosite. They believed the research slowed down when the tx was approved and that the studies they'd seen were too short-lived to be good prognosticators of success. They would go ahead with it in extremely limited circumstances - patient would have to be post-menopausal, for example. They were also wary of the selling that went on with it.  That said, it is quite popular in some parts of the country. I believe Johns Hopkins has a study open right now on its usage or shorter term rad tx. Hopefully you just got a bad egg and that person is not indicitive of the company.  Do you know if the person who examined you was an employee of the company?  I have heard of that happening in other medical cases (unrelated to mammosite). Best wishes for successful treatment...it sounds like you have a good team behind you now.
Posts.Title: MammoSite Sales Job KarenX KarenX

Posts.Content: Oct 28, 2008 07:57PM PSK07 wrote: Oh, Annie of the Camel Droppings...  Rads. Now, I only had rads, so I'm not much of one to ask, but I was wiped out by the end of the first week.  Not tired, but bone-weary. My rad onc said he had one patient who slept 24 hours a day, and then there were those who kept up a full work schedule + exercise through the whole thing. He was surprised that it took me down so soon...it's usually about 2 weeks in before the first SEs appear.  For me, the anxiety associated with rads was probably enough to put me over the edge.  They did tell me to eat a high-protein diet - plenty of red meat....mmmmm red meat. (No PETA girl here) They gave me pure Aloe gel. I used it first thing in the morning, after showering, at lunch time (before the exercising stopped), right after treatment, and before bed.  My tx were at 4:00, and they wanted at least 3 hours between application and rads. I started using it with Tx #1. I also stopped wearing a bra and went with shelf bra camis bought in bulk from Costco.  With bulky sweaters over, I felt comfortable at work.  I did not wash it off.... Once the burn started (half-way through), I continued with Aloe, used Aquaphor at night & weekends (old clothes because it stains), and used whatever crap they threw at me - domeboro solution, gel pads, you name it...lidocaine when it got really bad.  A year later you can still see the lovely tan line, but no adverse skin effects. Bottom line is to take it easy. Unlike chemo brain, rads brain truly is short term (I had to stop reading for the duration), but it can wipe you out. I'll be thinking of you.....
Posts.Title: Questions about rads protocol HeatherBLocklear Kleenex

Posts.Content: Oct 2, 2007 05:58PM PSK07 wrote: I had one - they did the ultra sound to find the mass seen in the MRI, then followed up with the u/s-guided biopsy. Local anesthetic, then the needle inserted and the snap when they took the sample(s). Relatively painless, just ice on and off for the rest of the day. The not showering for the day or 2 after was the worst of it.  Actually being able to see what was going on and to ask questions during the process was a plus. Pam

He said that while he'd be happy to see me again, it wasn't necessary, to just include him on copies of mammos/MRI/ultrasounds and let him know if there are any issues. My PCP ordered my MRI and the breast center sends me reminders to schedule mammos.  Now that I'm seeing a medical oncologist for Tamoxifen, I'll see her every 6 months til I'm done with it. He is a great doctor - I think since I met with him at least weekly for almost two months, it was  easy to build up a rapport with him.  We parted on a so-we-hope-we-never-have-to-see-each-other-ever-again kind of thing.
Posts.Title: 2 years out--- do I need to see the rad onc? turtle42 ginger2345

Posts.Content: Mar 9, 2009 04:53PM PSK07 wrote: Cathie - my mom and I were talking on Saturday about people and their very different reactions/SEs to cancer treatments. She had chemo 18 years ago and really never regained her pre-dx energy levels, plus chemo brain still lingers. I had rads only and the rads fatigue hit me like a ton of bricks. Oh, how I wanted to be one of those who ran marathons throughout rads... it so didn't happen!  The effects are cumulative. Mine really kicked in and I was off work from the end of week 2 through 2 weeks post-rads. My brain was numb, couldn't concentrate (books with a plot were out), and while I was very active prior, couldn't do much of anything. I was totally unable to handle my high-intensity job, and TG for my company, I was eligible for short term disability. It was Christmas time & I have no clue how anything got done.  My rad onc said he had women who slept 23 hours a day and others who ran the marathons. You just never know - he thought I'd do fine.  Like others have said, get plenty to drink and eat lots of protein (I craved fried eggs), and be as active as you want to be; it can only help. Otherwise, just listen to your body and do what you can to be as comfortable as you can. It will be over soon, and you will recover.  Thankfully, the SEs are short term and temporary. Good luck and take care!

Posts.Content: Nov 23, 2007 08:33PM PSK07 wrote: Hi NWSailor, Of course any decision is yours alone.  If the DCIS is localized, that 1cm is it, then bi-lateral mastectomy may be overkill. DCIS isn't invasive and is the one BC that you can truly be cured of.  That said, only you can say what kind of risk you can live with.  Before I started radiation, my rad onc ordered another mammo to ensure everything was taken out in surgery (it was). Rads will cut my risk of recurrence in 1/2, and if I take tamoxifen, my recurrence risk will drop further. I'm only 46, and I worry about the future, but we decided to fight what I have now rather than what I could have.  Wanting to take off for a couple of years sailing certainly changes the equation and your surgeon and onc team should be able to tell you what kind of follow-up is necessary in both circumstances - that may give you your answer.  Best wishes to you.  Come visit the DCIS conversation below. There are women there you have made the decision for mastectomy and they can probably offer plenty of insight. take care.

Posts.Content: Dec 13, 2007 01:55PM PSK07 wrote: I've gone with the instructions given me by the rad onc and what's on radiologyinfo.org - no antiperspirants (the aluminum can interfere with the beam effectivity), no razor, no deodorant soap, no fragranced soap/lotion. I can use aloevera, glycerin soap, Dove, and aquaphor. I use the razor on the non-tx side, but my right side is starting to look pretty bad.  Since that skin is pretty red and tender at the moment, using a razor is the last thing on my mind.

Posts.Content: Nov 9, 2007 11:45PM PSK07 wrote: geebung - I am a digital convert. My center went to all digitals in June.  It went much better than all my prior mammos, even though I didn't like the resulting diagnosis .  What I liked: almost instant feedback. After my callback, the radiologist took me back to look at the mammo on the monitor and could point out exactly what they were looking at - zooming in, magnifying, it was unreal. The problem area was easily seen by me, a rank beginner.

Posts.Content: Dec 21, 2007 08:30PM PSK07 wrote: Joni- I met with two rad oncologists - the second as another opinion on getting rads. The first one was leaning towards no rads, the second very pro-rads. I ended up having rads & stayed with the first doctor. Even having met with someone else (he suggested I get another opinion before deciding) did not in any way influence the care I've received.  Given that you'll be having treatments daily for over 6 weeks,  and the most commonly reported side effect is fatigue, convenience is something to consider as well as whether it is a state-of-the art facility. Oh - as it happened, my surgeon is one of the top in the area as reported by a local magazine. All well and good, but the fact that he is the one other doctors send their families to made a bigger impression. take care

Posts.Title: hate My Rads Oncologist and Not doing follow up QueenK lookingforward4more

Posts.Content: Apr 27, 2008 03:56AM PSK07 wrote: Hi, m. At what age was your mom diagnosed?  The typical mammo is 40, but with a first-degree relative, they usually want you to have one at 40 or when you're 10 years younger than your relative at her first occurrence, whichever is earlier.  I was 46, so my girls will have theirs at 36.  My mom's occurence was when she was 62, so I had my first at 40.  There's nothing that says that you're in the clear til 40, and the younger mom was when she was dx, the more you need to be vigilant.  If the doc is worried about breast density, digital mammos and especially MRIs can provide clearer pictures. take care. Best to you and your mom.
Posts.Title: when should i have my first mamogram? myhueandcry jezza

Posts.Content: Dec 16, 2008 03:48PM - edited Dec 16, 2008 03:53PM by PSK07 I would get the mammo. You're over 40, had your first child after age 30 (?), and have already had callbacks and one biopsy.  As far as family history of BC, many BC patients have no family history at all.  The radiation levels are so low - about as much as flying coast-to-coast - and while it is theoretically possible to get cancer from mammograms, you'd probably have to have multiple images every day for ages for that to happen.  If your center has digital mammography, the radiation levels are lower than with standard mammos. Like Beesie, I had  DCIS.  It didn't present in a lump, so without the mammogram it wouldn't have been found.  The US standard is every year after 40 and I'd rather risk the radiation from a mammogram than have a later-stage cancer found that could have been detected much earlier. It's a good idea since you had a biopsy last year & they can check for changes since then. (For me, a biopsy of a spot last year was b9 - but they saw some growth this year and did another biopsy and found pre-cancerous cells...ya never know.) Anyway - talk to your PCP or even to a radiologist (perhaps the one who did the biopsy last year). They can help you assess your risk and what is the best testing scenario that fits not only your risk profile, but your risk tolerance as well.  And that is certainly something that none of us here can come close to doing. And remember, most of us here have been through cancer and (hopefully) back, so we tend to be a bit biased...:) Take care.

Posts.Content: Jan 12, 2008 05:28PM PSK07 wrote: I am a C-D cup & wore shelf bra camisoles or tight t-shirts through my radiation. I couldn't stand to have anything tight around me & under my breast got quite burned during tx, so I wouldn't have been able to wear a bra anyway. The fabric came up high under my arms, so I avoided the skin-to-skin contact the rad techs discouraged. Over the cami I wore loose tops or sweaters or jackets. By the end, the headlight look was not attractive. 2 weeks post rads, I'm still wearing the camis, but will wear a bra next week when I go back to work. Everything is healed and the red has faded to tan. Good luck and good results to you.

Posts.Content: Sep 27, 2008 09:58PM PSK07 wrote: If you're having a mastectomy, a SNB is usually called for as once the tissue is removed they can't do a SNB.  For a 'regular' lumpectomy with DCIS, a SNB isn't necessary. Once the pathology is back, if they determine that there is an IDC microinvasion there, they can always go back and do the SNB. Like MAMHOP says, not doing one is standard of care. take care
Posts.Title: not checking nodes sunflower45 Jo_Ann_K

Posts.Content: Jan 20, 2008 11:48PM PSK07 wrote: Otter - this is a decision that has to feel right for you. While your husband can weigh in, it is your body and your level of risk tolerance.  I've told my husband many times - he can say whatever he wants, but ultimately I am the one who has to live with it. This goes for simple things like hair cuts to complex things like surgery. Friends do not get to weigh in. Honestly, with my dx, I had no reason to consider a mastecomy, and I didn't. While rads were being debated, my rad onc took the step of setting up a 2nd opinion with a colleague, we ended up reversing initial decision & I still had rads under his care. Left side rads still carry the risk of heart and lung damage. That's what would concern me risk-wise.  You still hear of women who end up with problems so I don't think it is something to be dismissed lightly. Put all that with the distance from the clinic and it would be a hard sell for me! (My exhaustion with rads was overwhelming & there is no way I could have done it without being at home w/family.)    If you can get a good cosmetic result, a good surgical outcome (the lumps can be removed cleanly and aren't positioned so you'd need rads anyway), a risk of recurrence lower than lx + rads, and above all you want a mastectomy - then go for it. Docs can offer alternatives, but when it comes right down to it, it is your body, your cancer, your risk, your decision. It isn't like you are wanting to do some bizarre out-there treatment for cryin' out loud! And with small breasts, a lumpectomy could very well end up being as close as you can get to a full mastectomy. Paste your list back together, maybe get another opinion, but it sure sounds like you have thought it through carefully!

Posts.Content: Apr 18, 2008 07:38PM PSK07 wrote: A lot depends on whether your insurance will pay for something other than standard 5 weeks, so be sure and check. Mammosite is being used more often,(although many docs don't use it on pre-menopausal women) but it isn't necessarily common. The 'Canadian' method - a shorter duration is used some places as well.  Some of the SEs of the shorter, but stronger, rads treatments are the same as the std 5 weeks, only more intense.  There are contraptions they can use to minimize the effects of rads on heart and lungs, and the targeting is incredibly precise, but there are always risks. My main SE was fatigue - bone-wearying, deep down, completely fogged, fatigue. Not sleepy-tired, but flat-on-my-back exhaustion. Took about 4 weeks to get back up to snuff. (I had 35 tx) Each treatment lasted only a few minutes and they gave me warm towels. :) Look at http:\\www.radiologyinfo.org for information on some of the therapies. Take care.

Posts.Title: ER- & PR- ?? /Surgeon vs. Rad. Onc. LUVmy2girlZ LUVmy2girlZ

Posts.Content: Feb 19, 2009 01:05PM PSK07 wrote: Rose is correct - Tamoxifen does not put you into menopause. In fact, my onc was very, very clear about it - while I am taking tamoxifen I either use two kinds of non-hormonal BC (condoms+spermicide), get sterilized, or husband has the big V. You will continue to ovulate and if you become pregnant, the tamoxifen can seriously damage the fetus. That said, you can stop taking tamoxifen at any time and if you took it for 2 years, went off it long enough for it to clear your system, got preg, had baby...well, it happens. There are side effects and there are risks. If I had issues with blood clots I wouldn't take it. It's really a matter of looking at your own risks and what tamoxifen can do for you. The younger you are, the less likely you are to get some of the most serious SEs (cancers, clots, strokes) associated with the drug. Things change. Your onc wants you to consider taking it in 4 years. A lot can happen in 4 years. You may have a different onc who doesn't prescribe tamoxifen (the first onc I saw didn't.) You may have more things show up or not.  You may or may not even have the same partner. Taking charge of fertility while in your early 30's is probably a good idea, though. And I'd be asking the onc if s/he was offering to set up the college fund or else keep quiet. You certainly have a lot to think about, and a lot of it is uncomfortable. Since I am the master procrastinator I would put the tamoxifen decision out of my mind for another couple of years, live as fully as I can now, keep up the monitoring, and think long and hard about children and timing. I hope it gets easier.
Posts.Title: decline taking tamoxifen despite onc's recommendation? SecretAgentL PSK07

Posts.Content: Dec 30, 2008 09:16PM PSK07 wrote: I had my initial biopsy scheduled by the radiologist at the breast center; I didn't meet with a surgeon until the pathology came back and I had to think about next steps. IIRC, I had the mammo at the end of June-beginning of July and the biopsy at the end of July, so your timing is not unusual. Scheduling can sometimes be difficult.   Funny how you forget things...I think it was the same this year - the radiologist rec'd an MRI-guided biopsy, I had it done & then met with the surgeon. Since there is a tumor board at the hospital, it is entirely possible that my case was presented, but my dealings were through the breast center and radiology (they are dedicated to BC). So far, I've had a stereotactic, an ultra-sound-guided, and an MRI-guided. Maybe because they are radiology driven? Talk to them about getting in sooner - maybe if there is a cancellation. Sometimes they need a nudge. Good luck to you. Pam

Posts.Title: Very advanced B.C. A Commentary. Bimmer Bren-2007

Posts.Content: Dec 3, 2007 02:15AM PSK07 wrote: Hi, Joni I am currently getting radiation tx for DCIS - had the lumpectomy at the end of September. My surgeon had me get an MRI as well.  His rationale was that we find out everything we can before he cuts - if there was something on the left that we hadn't seen, or more on the right than what was found on the biopsy, better to find it then. Measure twice, cut once. The MRI did find something in my left breast which prompted an ultrasound and u/s-guided biopsy.  False positives are very common though with MRI & I was fortunate to be on the good side of 80%/20% that time. It is very nervewracking to go through these tests and the relief you feel when they're done is like no other. Good luck to you & hoping everything comes up clear.
Posts.Title: MRI tomorrow JoniB candie1971

Posts.Content: Feb 1, 2009 05:39PM PSK07 wrote: helene - when I've been scheduled for my MRIs, the center (and my doc) has been very careful to make certain that it is done between days 7-10 of my cycle.  The false positives are supposed to be greatly reduced by that timing. The pre-surgical MRI I had in 2007 found a very small 'thingy' which was pronounced benign after an ultrasound-guided biopsy.  The MRI I had in August 2008 showed enhancement as well as some growth of this tiny 'thingy' so it was biopsied again. Probably because it was slightly larger, they were able to get better samples & I was diagnosed with LCIS.    I have to say that my experiences have been good - the people they have doing the MRIs do breasts only and the radiologist and nurse are from the breast center as well.   In my mind, the more breast imaging experience they have, the better their diagnosis ability. good luck.
Posts.Title: What has been your experience with MRI and dense breast tissue? helene333 helene333

Posts.Content: Nov 26, 2007 11:19PM PSK07 wrote: Hi, Traci I've never had a fine-needle aspiration, so I can't help you there. I've had a couple of biopsies - one stereotactic and one ultrasound-guided. With both, they gave me a local anesthetic. I'm not much for needles, either, and found it easiest to just look away from what they were doing. It didn't hurt, mostly just uncomfortable, and took about 30-45 minutes each. You may want to talk to your dr about an anti-anxiety drug to take before the procedure to help calm you down. These things are tough enough without having to deal with nerves as well. For the stereotactic biopsy I was in there by myself, but for the u/s one my husband was able to be in the room with me, which was a huge comfort. 80% of the lumps and bumps turn out to be benign, so the odds are definitely on your side. Take care and best hopes for a benign result.
Posts.Title: Scared of Biopsy traci_t wvgirl

Posts.Content: Nov 2, 2008 02:55PM PSK07 wrote: Hi, Jen I had my partial mastectomy/lumpectomy a week ago Friday. I was admitted, wheeled over to the breast center for the wire insertion (slight pain, but doctor was very good) - kept my eyes shut as much as possible, then back to the day surgery unit.  I got to put on the lovely gown, had all the vital stats taken, and the IV inserted. I do not like needles, so I kept my eyes averted. Surgery was about an hour. I woke up and was moved into recovery about an hour later. I was wrapped in the 40-ft long ace bandage for 24 hours.  Headache for awhile, but they gave me darvocet and I was fine.  Wore sweatpants and a loose shirt that buttoned up the front home. Ok. They this time they took out about a ping pong ball size of tissue and the incision is about an inch and a half long. No real pain - took pain killers for the first 36 hours - mostly discomfort. I was able to take a shower Saturday evening & remove the huge bandage, leaving only the steristrips. I wore a sportsbra 24 hours a day til I went back to work on Thursday (I am a wuss with a lot of sick leave saved up) & since then at night.  I was able to remove the steristrips yesterday (w/surgeon's permission). Incision site is kind of ugly.  The IV site still has a bit of a bruise & honestly that hurts more than the lumpectomy site.  My recovery has been relatively easy - last year's surgery was a bit worse, mostly because of the position on the breast.  I had to take it easy on lifting things, but other than some low BP issues, its ok.  I have a good surgeon and good skin, & the scar on last year's incision has faded a lot. The hospital gave me a small pillow to use to support the breast while sleeping or sitting.  No lymphedema issues for me because no lymph nodes were taken - which is pretty standard with DCIS and this LCIS nodule. Take care and good wishes for the surgery and outcome.
Posts.Title: Lumpectomy - what to expect JenP2008 PSK07

Hmmm. What should I do then?  I didn't take any precautions after last year's surgery and haven't so far with this one (10 days ago). I lift weights, get BP checks.... Help!

Posts.Content: Nov 4, 2008 04:39PM PSK07 wrote: Thanks, Binney Since I've had trouble in the past with both shoulders, I am very careful as far as noticing any pain or discomfort when lifting weights or doing any exercise. It's a body pump class & we use weighted bars & the instructor is big on doing things right which probably helps.  After last year's surgery I took a good 3 weeks to start back in & took time to build back up to where I was prior. I'll do the same now.  Mom's had the lymphatic massage/therapy & it does help some. A couple of years after her surgery, someone I worked with had a MRM as well, and one of the first things my mom said to tell her was to take precautions against lymphedema. She did. I will take a look at your links & see what I can do to reduce my risk.  Thank you so much!  Every day here I learn something more.

Posts.Content: Dec 30, 2007 01:35AM PSK07 wrote: I was off for a week following my lumpectomy (no SNB) - the general anesthesia took a long time to get over. I also had plenty of sick leave to use. I worked full-time + til rads started 6 weeks later w/no ill effects The main radiation side effect was fatigue & it affected me to the extreme. Had I not had paid short term disability and sick leave available, I probably would have sucked it up and worked the entire time. As it was, I stopped working at 3 weeks in & will be off for another 2 weeks for a total of 5 weeks. If you're able to get people to help w/housework and cooking, and you can get plenty of rest (like do nothing) outside of work, you will probably do just fine. Chemo, I didn't have. take care.
Posts.Title: Recovery time heimbca Shirlann

Posts.Content: Jan 10, 2009 11:01PM PSK07 wrote: I am always happy to read of women who experienced no fatigue or issues with rads...proves it can happen!  My onc told me that he had one patient who slept 20+ hours a day and others who did just fine - there was no rhyme or reason to it.  He assured me I'd do ok. Me - I was exhausted.  I did my normal eating/exercise/gym routine for as long as I could, but by week 2 the fatigue started and I ended up on medical leave. Fuzzy brain, wiped out mentally and physically. Not tired, just bone-weary.  I was off work for 6 weeks and it took probably 2-3 months before I was completely back to normal.  No residual issues. Skin still has a slight tan (1 year out), but that's it. No leathery skin, no extra firmness or anything. I got back into my gym routine as soon as I could.  (I do think there was a good part of me that just needed the respite from work and it manifested itself in rads exhaustion, but I had the med leave and disability avail, so I took it.) Take it day to day, rest when you need to, eat plenty of protein, drink lots of liquids. May you be on the easy end of the spectrum!

Posts.Content: Oct 29, 2008 02:49PM PSK07 wrote: Tera I had an MRI last year prior to my surgery for DCIS.  They saw something & did an ultra-sound guided biopsy on it. Came back benign. When I had an MRI in August, the same nodule had grown some & there was increased washout. The biopsy this time found LCIS in it (could have been a sampling error from last year, who knows). The radiologist recommended it come out - LCIS isn't cancer, but she felt it better to remove it and then not have to worry about that particular thingy anymore.  The oncologist felt the same way.  Someone here says that the only good lump is in a jar...I'm inclined to believe her. Getting it out gives me one less thing to obsess over!  The only way they can really tell if something is a problem is to biopsy and/or remove it.  good luck & hoping for benign results for you.

Posts.Content: Dec 14, 2008 07:11PM PSK07 wrote: Hi, momonjava I had DCIS last year, treated with lumpectomy and rads.  In August/September this year I was dx with LCIS and ALH  in the other breast. A nodule that was biopised as B9 last year showed some growth and increased washout, so they did another biopsy.  Since there was a nodule, it meant another lumpectomy for me.  Leaf is right on the treatment options. My treatment will be tamoxifen for 5 years and alternating mammos and MRIs every 6 months. (I had DCIS, so I can't use another anti-hormonal/AI). If something else shows up along the line, it will mean bi-lat mx, so I'm going with the drugs.   I hope the rib pain is leftover rads SE and everything else comes out well. Posts.Content: Feb 6, 2008 09:50AM PSK07 wrote: Shay - If it is in one quadrant, it's possible to still do the lumpectomy/partial mastectomy, but it depends on how big an area and the size of the breast, and where it's located. The only way to get rid of pure DCIS is to remove it - chemo isn't an option. Radiation will kill remaining cells.  If you have DCIS with an invasive component (which takes it from stage 0 to stage 1), it's treated as stage 1. That's where my knowledge stops as mine had no micro-invasions.  If you're ER/PR-, you can't take tamoxifen, so your treatment options could be different still. take care.

Posts.Content: Sep 13, 2007 10:08PM PSK07 wrote: Sue- I think exhaustion is just part of being a mom. That said, the past 6 weeks have knocked me out. I am foggier than usual and go from not being able to sleep to dropping into the deepest, hardest sleep possible.  I take an anti-depressant and it doesn't seem to be working the same way since the dx. My mom had a mastectomy 17 years ago. She had some music therapy tapes, designed to be used prior to and during surgery. They worked so well, her vitals were steady, she was so calm, had no blood loss, and was in a great state for recovery.  She credits being mentally ready for the good result. (Of course, getting through chemo and its aftermath were another story, but times and meds have changed.) I had an inkling about my DX, and I don't really know why. I remember thinking in June, before my mammo, that if something was found I'd still go on vacation, etc. The DX was a shock, but somehow I knew it would happen. Knowing what is going on and getting through each step is empowering.  Tomorrow I visit my surgeon and we'll discuss today's ultrasound and biopsy (for a tiny spot on the other breast, probably benign) and start making plans for the lumpectomy. Take a deep breath and rest and relax as much as you can. My pug sits next to me and it surely helps... Pam
Posts.Title: please help sueps barbe1958

Posts.Content: Oct 6, 2007 06:09PM - edited Oct 6, 2007 07:19PM by PSK07 Sue, Please do something for yourself, even if it is just a long bath. You get to start on the next phase now...just think how far you've gotten. This is doable. So hard, but doable. Funny. I can sit in front of a (male) doctor I've never seen before, boobs hanging out for the world to see, discussing the percentage of women with two different sized breasts, yet I lived in terror that my period would start while I was under the knife (it held off for 24 hours).  You have to laugh. Last night I was trying to figure out what pills to take before bed. There's the anti-depressant, the antibiotic for my skin, both givens, the Darvoset, the Xanax, the Ambien, Motrin, Oxycodone, we could finance our kids' education on the drug cabinet alone.
